docs.snippet: Even an experienced traveler can succumb to 24-TDD, 24-hour Temporary and Distress and Disorientation, on the first day in a new town....
docs.lead_paragraph: A traveler arrives in London, jet-lagged, throws his bags down in the hotel in Islington and sets out to meet a friend at Kings College, which Google Maps says is a 30-minute walk away. A half-hour later he’s lost and caught in pouring rain. Forty-five minutes later he’s wandering Fleet Street with a cheap umbrella in hand. An hour and a Tube ride later, this soaked and stressed shadow of his former self gives his impatient friend a hug.

headline.main: When You’ve Got Those First-24-Hour Blues

docs.snippet: Google dipped its toes into the world of travel in July when it announced a new Web-based tool, Hotel Finder, while Orbitz expanded its presence with Orbitz-Hotels.      Hotel Finder (google.com/hotelfinder), limited to the United States, displays...
docs.lead_paragraph: Google dipped its toes into the world of travel in July when it announced a new Web-based tool, Hotel Finder, while Orbitz expanded its presence with Orbitz-Hotels. Hotel Finder (google.com/hotelfinder), limited to the United States, displays search results on a list or a map. What's distinctive is that it lets users define their own search parameters by superimposing an outline on the map. For a hotel search in New York City you could, say, set the outline to show hotels below 14th Street. Once you have found a hotel, Google lets you know if you are getting a deal by comparing that day's rate with the hotel's normal rate.

headline.main: Seeking a Hotel? Here Are Two New Tools

docs.snippet: Q.I have scanned family photos for a reunion that I'd like to put online, but what's the best way to move them all to the Web (and not on Facebook), and how can I keep them private for only relatives to see?     A. Scout around for a photo-sharing...
docs.lead_paragraph: Q.I have scanned family photos for a reunion that I'd like to put online, but what's the best way to move them all to the Web (and not on Facebook), and how can I keep them private for only relatives to see? A. Scout around for a photo-sharing site that meets your needs in terms of the amount of data you can upload, as well as privacy options. Depending on what Web services you already use, you may have photo-sharing space and not realize it. For example, Hotmail users can take advantage of Microsoft's Windows Live SkyDrive to upload and share photos and Gmail users can easily get started with Google's Picasa Web albums.

headline.main: Online Photos For The Family

docs.abstract: Personal Tech Q&A on moving photos online but keeping them private, and making videoconference calls on Skype (M)

docs.snippet: Google made a $12.5 billion bet on Monday that its future - and the future of big Internet companies - lies in mobile computing, and moved aggressively to take on its arch rival Apple in the mobile market.     The Silicon Valley giant, known for i...
docs.lead_paragraph: Google made a $12.5 billion bet on Monday that its future - and the future of big Internet companies - lies in mobile computing, and moved aggressively to take on its arch rival Apple in the mobile market. The Silicon Valley giant, known for its search engine and Android phone software, rattled the tech world with its announcement that it would acquire Motorola Mobility Holdings, allowing it to get into the business of making cellphones and tablets.

headline.main: $12 Billion Deal Will Put Google In Mobile Market

docs.abstract: Google announces that it will acquire Motorola Mobility Holdings for $12.5 billion, allowing it to get into the business of making cellphones and tablets; move is a bold wager that company's future, along with other big Internet companies, lies in mobile computing, and is an aggressive strategy for challenging archrival Apple in the mobile market; photos (M)

byline.original: By EVELYN M. RUSLI; Steve Lohr, Verne G. Kopytoff and Michael J. de la Merced contributed reporting

docs.snippet: Google, in announcing a $12.5 billion deal for Motorola Mobility on Monday, saved its warmest words not for Motorola Mobility's management or its products, but for one valuable asset: the company's roughly 17,000 patents, as well as an additional ...
docs.lead_paragraph: Google, in announcing a $12.5 billion deal for Motorola Mobility on Monday, saved its warmest words not for Motorola Mobility's management or its products, but for one valuable asset: the company's roughly 17,000 patents, as well as an additional 7,500 patents that are under government review. That intellectual property portfolio is a treasure trove for Google because the battle in wireless is one that is increasingly being fought in court.

headline.main: Google's Coup Shifts Mobile Alliances: In the World of Wireless, It's All About the Patents

docs.snippet: Apple has a cash problem. It's not just that Apple has too much cash, $76 billion as of June 30. It's rather that the bulk of that pile, estimated at $41 billion, is held abroad.     Apple does not want to bring it back to the United States for se...
docs.lead_paragraph: Apple has a cash problem. It's not just that Apple has too much cash, $76 billion as of June 30. It's rather that the bulk of that pile, estimated at $41 billion, is held abroad. Apple does not want to bring it back to the United States for several reasons, primarily because of the tax consequences, but also because of its own growing foreign presence. Apple is not alone - this problem is an increasing one in corporate America. And the answer may not be more big, all-cash acquisitions, like Google's $12.5 billion offer for Motorola Mobility.

headline.main: Bringing Cash Piles Back Home

docs.abstract: Steven M Davidoff Deal Professor column suggests that changes to tax policy will allow American multinational corporations to repatriate some of the estimated $1.37 trillion in cash held outside of the United States (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: OTTAWA - Ever since the introduction of its first BlackBerry more than a decade ago, Research in Motion has defied expectations that it would be gobbled up by a larger rival and has effectively created the market for smartphones. But as Google moves to buy Motorola Mobility, RIM, already under pressure from diminished prospects and declining market share, is once again the subject of takeover talk.

headline.main: In Mobile Takeover Talks, RIM Resurfaces as Target

docs.snippet: HEFTY FEE Google proved it was willing to pay up for Motorola Mobility, agreeing to buy the cellphone maker for $12.5 billion, a 63.5 percent premium. But the search engine giant was also willing to offer a significant reverse termination fee to g...
docs.lead_paragraph: HEFTY FEE Google proved it was willing to pay up for Motorola Mobility, agreeing to buy the cellphone maker for $12.5 billion, a 63.5 percent premium. But the search engine giant was also willing to offer a significant reverse termination fee to guarantee that it was committed to the deal. Google's deal contained a $2.5 billion reverse breakup fee, according to people with direct knowledge of the matter who spoke on condition of anonymity. That's roughly 20 percent of the purchase price. MICHAEL J. de la MERCED

docs.snippet: Google's $2.5 billion reverse termination fee for Motorola Mobility sends a statement that the deal should clear antitrust review....
docs.lead_paragraph: It is certainly big. But is there any chance that it will be paid? I'm talking about the $2.5 billion reverse termination fee that Google agreed to pay Motorola Mobility if its proposed takeover fails to obtain antitrust clearance. This fee is about 20 percent of the $12.5 billion deal value and is significantly higher than the $375 million Motorola Mobility must pay Google if it accepts another bid.

docs.lead_paragraph: ''What freaked me out today was that Philly Fed number.'' James W. Paulsen, chief investment strategist at Wells Capital Management. On Thursday, stocks plunged after the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia reported a sharp drop in regional manufacturing activity, deepening worries that the economy may dip back into recession. ''This is an emphatic exclamation point that Google is a mobile company.'' Ben Schachter, an analyst at Macquarie Capital, after Google announced that it would acquire Motorola Mobility Holdings, allowing it to get into the business of making cellphones and tablets. ''I'll compete again someday. My lips aren't going away.'' Christopher W. Ullman, global head of communications for the Carlyle Group, the private equity firm. He is a four-time international whistling champion, although the demands of Mr. Ullman's family and professional life have prevented him from competing in several years.

headline.seo: After Google, Motorola to Face Identity Crisis
headline.main: Motorola’s Identity Crisis

byline.original: By MATT RICHTEL and JENNA WORTHAM

docs.snippet: Hundreds of framed patents hang on two separate walls at the headquarters of Motorola Mobility in Libertyville, Ill. They testify to the pride in innovation at Motorola, a luminary of American business that has survived corporate crises and enormo...
docs.lead_paragraph: Hundreds of framed patents hang on two separate walls at the headquarters of Motorola Mobility in Libertyville, Ill. They testify to the pride in innovation at Motorola, a luminary of American business that has survived corporate crises and enormous technological change. But the company has never grappled with something like this: a murky future governed by Google, a powerful master with unclear intentions.

headline.main: Motorola's Identity Crisis

docs.abstract: Analysts wonder what is next for Motorola after Google's planned acquisition of Motorola Mobility; its future in the union, beyond its rich trove of 17,000 patents, is unclear, and there is speculation that Google could markedly pare back or sell big parts of Motorola that create conflicts with partners or are not central to its goals; drawing; photo (M)

byline.original: By MATT RICHTEL and JENNA WORTHAM

docs.snippet: Google, which announced the purchase of Motorola Mobility last week for $12.5 billion, is wading into a crowded mobile device market. Beyond the largest 10 makers in the second quarter, other companies accounted for a full third of market share (3...
docs.lead_paragraph: Google, which announced the purchase of Motorola Mobility last week for $12.5 billion, is wading into a crowded mobile device market. Beyond the largest 10 makers in the second quarter, other companies accounted for a full third of market share (35.8 percent). As important for Google (not to mention Apple and Research in Motion), jockeying continues for share of smartphone operating systems. Google's Android led in the second quarter, with 43 percent of the market, followed by Symbian (22 percent), Apple's iOS (18 percent) and RIM (12 percent).

headline.main: Popular Demand

docs.snippet: For merger advisers this year, it has been good to be an independent.     Two big deals last week - Google's $12.5 billion takeover bid for Motorola Mobility and Hewlett-Packard's $11.7 billion purchase of Autonomy - underscored the growing influe...
docs.lead_paragraph: For merger advisers this year, it has been good to be an independent. Two big deals last week - Google's $12.5 billion takeover bid for Motorola Mobility and Hewlett-Packard's $11.7 billion purchase of Autonomy - underscored the growing influence of boutique investment banks. Among the firms that helped propel the two transactions were Qatalyst Partners, Centerview Partners and Perella Weinberg Partners, as well as the biggest independent investment bank, Lazard.

headline.main: In Latest Deals, Big Roles for Boutique Investment Banks

byline.original: By MICHAEL J. DE LA MERCED

docs.snippet: In this week's podcast: a 9/11 app, Internet radio and tech support....
docs.lead_paragraph: With the tenth anniversary of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks just a few weeks away, the staff at the National September 11 Memorial & Museum is preparing to open this new site for visitors in Lower Manhattan. Sean Anderson, the chief technology officer for the organization, drops in  to The New York Times's Tech Talk podcast discuss the Explore 9/11 mobile app for those who want to understand the event more clearly. Mr. Anderson also outlines the other online educational materials the museum offers, including an interactive timeline, a virtual tour of the site with Google Earth, and the 9/11 Memorial's Web site.

headline.main: Tech Talk Podcast: Remembering 9/11
